facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 121 and 122 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Criminal Appeals Nos. 121 and 122 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 14, 1966 of the

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated March 14, 1966 of Mysore High Court in Criminal Revision Petitions Nos. 120 and 123 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 14, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Revision Petitions Nos. 120 and 123 of 1966 respectively.

facts.text: Appellants Pampapathy and Shekarappa tried in Court of Sessions at Chitradurga for offences under ss. 147, 148, 307, 323, 302 read with s. 149 and s. 325 read with s. 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants- Pampapathy and Shekarappa were tried in the Court of Sessions at Chitradurga for offences under ss. 147, 148, 307, 323, 302 read with s. 149 and s. 325 read

facts.text: Appellants convicted of all offences other than under s. 307 and s. 302 read with s. 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: with s. 149 of the Indian Penal Co and companyvicted of all the offences other than under s. 307 and s. 302 read with s. 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants by judgment dated December 7, 1964 for offences under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 325 read with s. 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge, by his judgment dated December 7, 1964 companyvicted both the appellants for offences under ss. 147, 148, 322 .324 and 325 read with s. 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeals to Mysore High Court and were released on bail on admission of appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred appeals to the Mysore High Court and on admission of the appeals they were directed to be released on bail.

facts.text: State made applications on March 7, 1966 under ss. 498(2) and 561A CrPC for cancellation of bail granted to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On March 7, 1966, the State made two applications under ss. 498 2  and 561A, Criminal Procedure Code for cancellation of the bail granted to the two appellants.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Deputy Superintendent of Police, Devangiri Division Sri K. Srinivasa Alwa alleging appellants misusing liberty by acts of violence, instigating unions, acting as ring leaders, unlawful assemblies.

anchor.surface_text: In support of the two petitions an affidavit was filed by the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Devangiri Division Sri K. Srinivasa Alwa, stating that the two appellants were misusing their liberty ever since they were enlarged on bail by doing acts of violence, creating trouble by instigating the labour unions of Devangiri Cotton Mills and Shankara Textile Mills to paralyse the smooth working of the Mills.

facts.text: Appellants filed counter affidavit denying allegations of acting in manner likely to cause breach of peace or endanger lives of workers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a companynteraf fidavit denying that they were acting in a manner likely to cause breach of peace or endanger the lives of the workers.

facts.text: Mysore High Court on March 14, 1966 allowed State's applications and cancelled bail, ordered rearrest and commitment to jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: On March 14, 1966 the Mysore High Court allowed the applications of the State and ordered that the bail granted to the appellants should be cancelled and they should be rearrested and companymitted to jailcustody.

facts.text: Prosecution case: appellants along with others formed unlawful assembly, armed with deadly weapons, attacked deceased Heggappa and other loyal workers on night of March 19, 1964, causing death of Heggappa and injuries to 4 persons.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was that the appellants, along with others, some of whom were dismissed workers of Devangiri Cotton Mills and Shri Ganeshar Textiles Mills and some of whom were office bearers and members of the Devangiri Cotton Mills Employees Association and Shri Ganeshar Textiles Mills Workers Union, companyspired with the companymon object of companymitting murder and other offences with a view to strengthen their Associations and to weaken the rival Unions which had the sympathy of the Mill Managements. It was alleged that they intended to create fear in the mind of the Management of the Mills in order to gain their object of getting more bonus and get the dismissed workers reinstated. It was stated that they formed themselves into an unlawful assembly, armed themselves with deadly weapons, and attacked the deceased Heggappa and other loyal workers on the night of March 19, 1964 causing the death of Heggappa and injuries to 4 persons.

facts.text: Crime No. 360 of 1965 registered on December 31, 1965 against appellants under ss. 143, 448 and 324 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: OnDecember 31, 1965 Crime No. 360 of 1965 was registeredagainst the appellants for companymission of the offencesunder ss. 143, 448 and 324, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Crime No. 53 of 1966 registered on February 11, 1966 against one of the appellants under ss. 341 and 323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1966 Crime No. 53 of 1966 was registered,in which one of the appellants was alleged to have companymitted offences under ss. 341 and 323, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Crime No. 54 of 1966 registered on February 12, 1966 against appellants under ss. 143, 147, 341, 323 and 324 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On February 12, 1966 yet another Crime No. 54 of 1966 was re- gistered against the appellants for the companymission of the offence under ss. 143, 147, 341, 323 and 324, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants are dismissed workers or office bearers/members of Devangiri Cotton Mills Employees Association and Shri Ganeshar Textiles Mills Workers Union.

anchor.surface_text: along with others, some of whom were dismissed workers of Devangiri Cotton Mills and Shri Ganeshar Textiles Mills and some of whom were office bearers and members of the Devangiri Cotton Mills Employees Association and Shri Ganeshar Textiles Mills Workers Union,

facts.text: Mysore High Court took view that allegations against appellants by State were well-founded and cancelled bail.

anchor.surface_text: but the High Court apparently took the view that the allegations against the appellants on behalf of the State were well-founded and the bail granted to them by the High Court should be cancelled.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals brought by special leave from Mysore High Court order dated March 14, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are brought, by special leave, from the order of the Mysore High Court dated March 14, 1966 in Criminal Petitions Nos. 120 and 123 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellants conspired with common object of committing murder to strengthen associations, weaken rival unions, create fear for more bonus and reinstatement of dismissed workers.

anchor.surface_text: companyspired with the companymon object of companymitting murder and other offences with a view to strengthen their Associations and to weaken the rival Unions which had the sympathy of the Mill Managements. It was alleged that they intended to create fear in the mind of the Management of the Mills in order to gain their object of getting more bonus and get the dismissed workers reinstated.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants: K. Ramamurthi, R. K. Garg and S. C. Agarwala.

facts.text: Appellants misusing liberty by constituting as ring leaders of Employees Association and committing offences against peaceful workers.

anchor.surface_text: It was also alleged that the appellants had companystituted themselves as ring leaders of the Employees Association and were taking part in unlawful assemblies at different times and had companymitted offences against the peaceful workers of the Mill.

issues.text: whether, in the case of a person convicted of a bailable offence where bail has been granted to him under s. 426 of the Criminal Procedure Code, it can be cancelled in a proper case by the High Court in exercise of its inherent power under s. 561A of the Criminal Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: The question of law arising for determination in these appeals is whether, in the case of a person convicted of a bailable offence where bail has been granted to him under s. 426 of the Criminal Procedure Code, it can be cancelled in a proper case by the High Court in exercise

issues.text: whether the case falls under s. 561A of the Criminal Procedure Code and whether it is a proper case in which the High Court should cancel bail even though it has power under s. 561A to do so

arguments.claim: High Court has no power to cancel bail granted under s.426 CrPC subsequently using s.561A as there is no express provision

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Ramamurthy on behalf of the appellants that after the High Court had once made an order suspending the sentence and granting bail to the appellants under s. 426, Criminal Procedure Code it had no power to cancel that order subsequently and recommit the appellants to jail- custody. It was submitted that there was no express power granted to the appellate court to cancel its order regarding the suspension of sentence pending the appeal and the order of release of the appellants on bail.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ue that in s. 498 and ss. 497 5  and 498 the legislature has made express provision for the cancellation of a bail bond in the case of accused persons

arguments.court_reasoning: Omission is due to oversight or inadvertence, not deliberate; leads to absurd results where even serious misconduct cannot justify cancellation; inherent power under s.561A fills the lacuna

arguments.claim: Legislature deliberately omitted express power to cancel bail under s.426, unlike s.497(5) and s.498(2), so s.561A cannot be used

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that under s. 497 5  the legislature has specifically conferred power on specified courts to cancel the bail granted to a person accused of a non-bailable offence. It was also pointed out by learned Counsel that under s. 498 2  the legislature has conferred power on the High Court and the Court of Session to cancel the bail granted to an accused person under s. 498 1  and ordering him to be arrested and committed to jailcustody.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: argument is that once an order of suspension of sentence is made under s. 426 by the appellate companyrt and the appellant is ordered to be released o

arguments.court_reasoning: Express provisions in other sections do not preclude inherent power; omission is oversight, not deliberate

arguments.claim: Even if appellants committed acts of violence or repeated offences while on bail, bail cannot be cancelled, only new prosecution under IPC

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Ramamurthy that even if the appellants committed acts of violence during the period they were enlarged on bail and repeated the very offence for which they had been convicted the bail bond could not be cancelled but the further conduct of the accused may justify another prosecution under the Indian Penal Code and that it would not justify the rearrest of the appellants.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e. Such a situation companyld number have been in the companytemplation of the legislature and, in our opinion, the omission to make an express provis

arguments.court_reasoning: Such interpretation leads to fantastic and absurd results, e.g., appellant could commit further crimes, threaten witnesses, abscond without court power to cancel

arguments.claim: High Court lacks power under s.498 to grant or cancel bail for convicted persons under appeal, per Lala Jairam Das; Ch.XXXIX and s.426 exhaustive

anchor.surface_text: In the course of argument Mr. Ramamurthy strongly relied upon the decision of the Judicial Committee in Lala Jairam Das v. King-Emperor. It was contended on behalf of the appellants that the High Court has no power to grant bail to a convicted person under s. 498 of the Criminal Procedure Code and therefore the provisions of s. 498 2  cannot be invoked to the present case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Code. It is true that all these decisions referred to cases of persons charged with number-bailable offences but it is significant that the provision

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedent concerns power to grant bail post-special leave to SC, not cancellation under inherent powers; ratio decidendi different and inapplicable

arguments.claim: High Court has inherent power under s.561A to cancel bail granted under s.426 in proper case to prevent abuse of process

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no justification for the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants... In a situation of this description the High Court is not helpless and in a proper case it may take recourse to the inherent power conferred upon it under s. 561A of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Pre-s.498(2) precedents support cancellation of bail under s.561A inherent powers

anchor.surface_text: We should like to add that, even before s. 498 2  was enacted, there was a consensus of judicial opinion in favour of the view that, if the accused person is released on bail under s. 498 1 , his bail bond could be cancelled and he could be ordered to be arrested and committed to custody under the provisions of s. 561A of the Code [citing cases].

arguments.claim: Case falls under s.561A as proper case for cancellation due to prima facie abuse of process by misuse of liberty
State's allegations against appellants well-founded, justifying bail cancellation

anchor.surface_text: but the High Court apparently took the view that the allegations against the appellants on behalf of the State were well-founded and the bail granted to them by the High Court should be cancelled.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court concurs; prima facie abuse supported by affidavit and crimes

holdings.text: in a proper case the High Court has inherent power under s. 561A, Criminal Procedure Code to cancel the order of suspension of sentence and grant of bail to the appellant made under s. 426, Criminal Procedure Code and to order that the appellant be rearrested and committed to jail-custody
holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of express provision in s.426 due to oversight or inadvertence, not deliberate; otherwise leads to absurd results where court powerless against misconduct; inherent power under s.561A fills lacuna and preserves pre-existing powers

holdings.text: even before s. 498(2) was enacted, there was a consensus of judicial opinion in favour of the view that, if the accused person is released on bail under s. 498(1), his bail bond could be cancelled and he could be ordered to be arrested and committed to custody under the provisions of s. 561A of the Code
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited precedents show inherent power under s.561A used for bail cancellation even absent express provision, not inconsistent with s.498(1); analogous to s.426 situation

holdings.text: the ratio decidendi of the decision of the Judicial Committee [in Lala Jairam Das] is therefore different and has no application to the present case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lala Jairam Das concerned power to grant bail post-special leave to Privy Council, not cancellation under inherent powers for s.426 bail

holdings.text: the allegations made against the appellants would prima facie indicate abuse of the process of the Court and the provisions of s. 561A are attracted to the case and the High Court was entitled to cancel the bail of the appellants under the provisions of that section

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the allegations made against the appellants would prima facie indicate abuse of the process of the Court and the provisions of s. 561A are attracted to the case and the High Court was entitled to cancel the bail of the appellants under the provisions of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State affidavit and registered crimes show misuse of liberty by violence, instigation, unlawful assemblies; High Court found allegations well-founded; constitutes prima facie abuse

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the allegations made against the appellants would prima facie indicate abuse of the process of the Court and the provisions of s. 561A

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the allegations made against the appellants would prima facie indicate abuse of the process of the Court and the provisions of s. 561A are attracted to the case and the High Court was entitled to cancel the bail of the appellants under the provisions of that section.

edges.explanation: Issue i1 directly addresses the concept c1 by questioning whether bail granted under s.426 can be cancelled using the High Court's inherent power under s.561A in a proper case.
Issue i1 specifically involves a person convicted of a bailable offence with bail under s.426, requiring the concept of bailable offence and its distinction including s.426 provisions.
